Situation2: You are currently reviewing the final briefs submitted by both parties for a complex civil trial that is scheduled to begin tomorrow morning.
Story: I stare at my phone, the screen lighting up with my friend’s name in a text: “Can we talk?” My stomach twists. I remember the offhand comment I made at dinner last night, meant as a joke, but I saw the way her face fell. I know I need to call her, to apologize, to explain myself and listen—really listen—so we can move past this. That’s what friends do: communicate, clear the air, make things right. But my desk is covered in case files, the final briefs for tomorrow’s trial. As a judge, I owe it to both parties to be fully prepared, to read every argument, every piece of evidence, so I can be fair and thorough in court. The clock ticks louder. My friend is waiting, probably hurting, but so are the lawyers and clients who expect my undivided attention. I feel pulled in two, the weight of both roles pressing on my chest, and I can’t ignore either. My hand hovers over the phone, heart pounding, as I try to decide which responsibility I can set aside, even for a moment.
